antonia

Well, I'll go first. I don't agree with creationist biology curriculum and I don't think it should be in the public school system. However, I believe that parents have a right to choose, within reasonable parameters, the sort of education their children receive, and that they have the right to use this curriculum free from interference by the state. Certainly, a teacher who sincerely believes in this curriculum, and sells it or promotes it, is within their rights and acting in accordance with what I would consider ethical boundaries. While a teacher who doesn't agree with the curriculum, and even opposes its use in the public school system, shows what an unprincipaled sort of individual they are -- that is, willing to compromise on what they really think for the sake of money and/or their idea of fame. Still, we live in a free society, meaning that even teachers are allowed to prostitute themselves. So, IMO, there is a principle at stake in terms of their individual liberties in (b). Therefore, I chose (c). Teachers who spy on parents and children, while teaching things they don't believe in, and abusing a position of trust, are the worst skunks. They threaten the very foundations of our democracy. 
 
 Note that (b) or (c) can also be chosen by creationists.
